newsitem.title: USA: Bay Q3 beats consensus, receivables improve.
newsitem.headline: Bay Q3 beats consensus, receivables improve.

text.p: Bay Networks Inc on Tuesday posted nil earnings per share for the third quarter because of restructuring charges, but its operating earnings beat Wall Street's tempered expectations for the period.

Reflecting a financial transition at the company, Bay Networks, a maker of data routers and switching equipment, said its third-quarter revenues were $512.9 million, down from $521.7 million in the year-ago quarter.
A highlight of the period was evidence that Bay had cut its accounts receivable. It said accounts receivable at March 31 were $295 million versus $321 million at June 30, 1996.
During the third quarter, the company said it had income from ongoing operations of $20.7 million, or $0.10 per share. The First Call consensus had called for $0.08 per share.
The latest quarter brought restructuring and severance charges of $32.2 million to cover workforce cuts and facilities closings. That reduced net earnings by $0.10 a share to the break-even level.

In a statement, Bay Networks said its switching and remote access businesses posted increases in the March quarter, as robust demand for Internet and intranet equipment helped the company overcome typical seasonal softness.
Bay said its cash position during the March quarter grew to $662.8 million, up about $43 million.

"We continue to make good progress on efforts to get our business back on track," said Dave House, chairman, president and chief executive of Bay Networks. "We have seen improving fundamentals in sales, marketing and product development."
House took over at Bay in November, after leaving a senior executive position at Intel Corp. Bay hired David Rynne, its new chief financial officer, in January.
Jospethal Lyon analyst Bert Hochfeld credited Bay with making progress in controlling inventories and introducing new products at more competitive price points during the quarter.
Inventories at March 31 amounted to $145.2 million, down from $239.7 million at June 30, 1996.
In March, for example, Bay announced a new product category called routing switches that fuse the merits of two historically distinct technologies -- routers and switches.
Hochfeld said the reduction in outstanding accounts receivable was "a very respectable" improvement. Still, he expected a more complete turnaround to take time.
"As impatient as we are in this business, (Bay CEO House) is not going to turn this company around after only a matter of months," Hochfeld said.
